ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My speaking improved a lot, and the rest of my language abilities also got much better.

I learned and solidified "survival" vocabulary and grammar structures, all while learning how to talk about certain crucial topics such as transportation, travel, food, parties, exercise, school, shopping, etc. I also strengthened my conversational skills.
I learned more Chinese grammar and vocab. I also learned more about Chinese culture.
several hundred characters and many grammar techniques, also much of chinese culture and exploration of personal heritage
Learned way more about Mandarin Chinese, especially in reading and writing. Learned a bit more about Chinese culture as a whole too.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The workload is manageable, and the course is highly engaging.

Strengths:
 - The rigor of the course, though demanding, keeps you accountable and helps you gain mastery of the material
 - The projects are fun and often collaborative
 - The heritage class particularly brings Asian students together into a community
 - Plentiful and timely feedback on writing
 
Weaknesses:
 - Class time would often be spent doing a lot of recitation off the board. I wish there was more discussion
More speaking practice with the new grammar and vocabulary outside of the class would be nice.

I believe the heritage track was very well taught. Very well catered to students with some natural fluency from a young age, and fun projects focusing on Chinese American identity. I think it could have been a bit more fast paced given everyone was Chinese, and the grading could be a bit modified so that written and oral responses were not solely graded on accuracy.

Strengths: the people in the class, the engaging class schedules and also the fun activities in class, like watching a movie.
Weaknesses: none.

I wished there were more chances to personally meet one-on-one with the teacher to discuss what could be improved. It felt like there wasn't too much room for student input, but rather everything was on a very strict schedule.
Amazing class, you have a good amount of work but I think it's definitely not too bad. The whole class flows pretty smoothly and I feel like I learned a lot

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely if you are a heritage student or have studied some Chinese before.
I cannot recommend this course enough to any Chinese American student. It provides you a different way of engaging with learning material at Yale.
Yes! Anyone who wants to take Chinese here at Yale I would heavily recommend. I can only speak for 112 and 122, but my experience has been of the highest quality!
Yes, you learn a lot and the teacher is very good.

Yes, if you are a Chinese American or have spoken Chinese from a young age, I would highly recommend it. Even if you dont know if you would enjoy learning Chinese or you are not as connected to your heritage, this course will definitely open up your mind to Chinese culture and identity. Learned a ton of Chinese as well, grading isnt too bad!
YES YES, learning Chinese, especially as a heritage speaker, is so rewarding and fun. The experience was so much fun and I honestly enjoyed every class and all my classmates.
